moves.1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Bb4: A sharp variation of the French.
moves.4. Nge2: A bit unusual perhaps, but this way if he captures...
moves.5. Nxc3: ...I still have a Knight guarding the KP.
moves.5... Ne7 6. Bb5+ Bd7 7. Bxd7+: I get rid of his second Bishop, leaving me at an advantage if a two-minor-piece end game arises.
moves.7... Nxd7 8. O-O O-O 9. e5: Creating the "cramping Pawn chain", although with two minor pieces gone from each side there's less to cramp, and setting up a possible K-side attack.
moves.9... c5 10. Be3 c4: Seizing Q-side space in response, but leaving the P at QB4 may have been better: now my QP is no longer under pressure.
moves.11. f4 Nf5 12. Bd2: I definitely don't want to give back the minor exchange.
moves.12... a6 13. Ne2: I begin to reassemble my forces towards the K-side.
moves.13... b5 14. Bb4: With the consideration that I don't want my B trapped behind my Pawn chain. Now it can participate in the coming attack.
moves.14... Re8 15. Ng3 Nxg3: This is a mistake, as it opens the KR file and lets my Rook have an avenue of attack.
moves.16. hxg3 a5 17. Bd6: This Bishop is destined to play a key role on this diagonal.
moves.17... a4 18. Kf2 Nb6 19. Rh1: Moving a big gun into position.
moves.19... Nc8 20. Bc5 Ne7: Hastily rushing to the K-side to defend.
moves.21. Qh5 h6 22. g4: Looking to batter down the obstructing Pawns.
This move breaks open my bro's defenses.
moves.23... gxf6 24. Qxh6: Threatening Q-R8 ch K-B2 R-R7 ch K-N3 Q-N7 mate.
moves.25. Qh8+: Carrying out the attack as planned.
moves.27. Qg7: Threatening BxN forking Q and R, and if BxN QxB??? QxQ mate.
moves.28. Rh8+: My brother resigned here. White has too many threats to defend against. If 28... K-Q2 29 RxQ ch followed by 30 QxR. If 28... N-N1 29 RxN ch, leaving Black the choice of 29... K-Q2 followed by previous variation, or 29... R-B1 30 RxR ch followed by 31 RxQ. If 28... R-B1 29 RxR ch followed by 30 RxQ.
